text: Adam, Seth, Enosh,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared,
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech,
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Japheth’s descendants were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gomer’s descendants were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Javan’s descendants were the people from Elishah, Tarshish, Cyprus, and Rhodes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ham’s descendants were Cush, Egypt, Put, and Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush’s descendants were Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. Raama’s descendants were Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush was the father of Nimrod, the first mighty warrior on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Egypt was the ancestor of the Ludites, Anamites, Lehabites, Naphtuhites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pathrusites, Casluhites (from whom the Philistines came), and the Caphtorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canaan was the father of Sidon his firstborn, then Heth,
speaker: Narrator

text: also the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, Aram, Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arpachshad was the father of Shelah, and Shelah was the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two sons were born to Eber. The name of the one was Peleg [Division], because in his day the earth was divided. His brother’s name was Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joktan was the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ebal, Abimael, Sheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were sons of Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shem, Arpachshad, Shelah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eber, Peleg, Reu,
speaker: Narrator

text: Serug, Nahor, Terah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram (that is, Abraham).
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham’s sons were Isaac and Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is their list of descendants: Ishmael’s firstborn was Nebaioth, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These were the sons of Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keturah, Abraham’s concubine, gave birth to the following sons: Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. Jokshan’s sons were Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was the father of Isaac. Isaac’s sons were Esau and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau’s sons were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliphaz’s sons were Teman and Omar, Zephi and Gatam, Kenaz and Amalek, son of Timna.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuel’s sons were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seir’s sons were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lotan’s sons were Hori and Homam. Timna was Lotan’s sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shobal’s sons were Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. Zibeon’s sons were Aiah and Anah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anah’s son was Dishon. Dishon’s sons were Hamran, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezer’s sons were Bilhan, Zaavan, Jaakan. Dishan’s sons were Uz and Aran.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the kings who ruled Edom before any king ruled the people of Israel: Bela, son of Beor, and the name of his capital city was Dinhabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Bela died, Jobab, son of Zerah from Bozrah, succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Husham died, Hadad, son of Bedad, who defeated the Midianites in the country of Moab, succeeded him as king, and the name of his capital city was Avith.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the river succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Shaul died, Baal Hanan, son of Achbor, succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Baal Hanan died, Hadad succeeded him as king, and the name of his capital city was Pai. His wife’s name was Mehetabel, daughter of Matred and granddaughter of Mezahab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Hadad died.
The tribal leaders of Edom were Timna, Aliah, Jetheth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
speaker: Narrator

text: Magdiel, and Iram. These were the tribal leaders of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were Israel’s sons: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah’s sons were Er, Onan, and Shelah. These three were born to him by Bathshua, a Canaanite woman. Yahweh considered Er, Judah’s firstborn, evil, so Yahweh killed Er.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tamar, Judah’s daughter-in-law, gave birth to Judah’s sons Perez and Zerah. Judah had five sons in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perez’s sons were Hezron and Hamul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zerah’s sons were Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara—five in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Carmi’s son was Achar, who caused trouble for Israel by taking goods that were claimed by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ethan’s son was Azariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons born to Hezron were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ram was the father of Amminadab. Amminadab was the father of Nahshon, leader of Judah’s people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahshon was the father of Salma, and Salma was the father of Boaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Boaz was the father of Obed, and Obed was the father of Jesse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse was the father of Eliab (his firstborn), Abinadab (his second son), Shimea (his third son),
speaker: Narrator

text: Nethanel (his fourth son), Raddai (his fifth son),
speaker: Narrator

text: Ozem (his sixth son), and David (his seventh son).
speaker: Narrator

text: Their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah’s three sons were Abishai, Joab, and Asahel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abigail was the mother of Amasa, whose father was Jether, a descendant of Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezron’s son was Caleb. Caleb and his wife Azubah had a son named Jerioth. Her other sons were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath. She gave birth to Hur.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hur was the father of Uri, and Uri was the father of Bezalel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, Hezron slept with the daughter of Machir, the man who first settled Gilead. Hezron had married her when he was 60 years old. She gave birth to Segub.
speaker: Narrator

text: Segub was the father of Jair, who had 23 towns in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Geshur and Aram captured Havvoth Jair with Kenath and its villages (60 cities in all). All of these people were descendants of Machir, the man who first settled Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Hezron died in Caleb Ephrathah, Hezron’s wife Abijah gave birth to Ashhur, who first settled Tekoa.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerahmeel (the firstborn son of Hezron) fathered Ram (his firstborn), then Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerahmeel had another wife. Her name was Atarah, and she was the mother of Onam.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ram (the firstborn son of Jerahmeel) were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.
speaker: Narrator

text: Onam’s sons were Shammai and Jada. Shammai’s sons were Nadab and Abishur.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Abishur’s wife was Abihail. She gave birth to Ahban and Molid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab’s sons were Seled and Appaim, but Seled died without children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Appaim’s son was Ishi, and Ishi’s son was Sheshan, and Sheshan’s son was Ahlai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jada (Shammai’s brother) were Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan’s sons were Peleth and Zaza. These were the descendants of Jerahmeel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheshan had no sons, but he had daughters. He had an Egyptian slave named Jarha.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheshan let Jarha marry one of his daughters. She gave birth to Attai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Attai was the father of Nathan. Nathan was the father of Zabad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zabad was the father of Ephlal. Ephlal was the father of Obed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obed was the father of Jehu. Jehu was the father of Azariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah was the father of Helez. Helez was the father of Eleasah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleasah was the father of Sismai. Sismai was the father of Shallum.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum was the father of Jekamiah. Jekamiah was the father of Elishama.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Caleb (Jerahmeel’s brother) were his firstborn son Mesha, who first settled Ziph, and the sons of Mareshah, who first settled Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hebron’s sons were Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shema was the father of Raham, who first settled Jorkeam. Rekem was the father of Shammai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shammai’s son was Maon, who first settled Beth Zur.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephah, Caleb’s concubine, was the mother of Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran was the father of Gazez.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahdai’s sons were Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Maacah, Caleb’s concubine, was the mother of Sheber and Tirhanah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, she was the mother of Shaaph, who first settled Madmannah, and of Sheva, who first settled Machbenah and Gibea. Caleb’s daughter was Achsah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These people were the descendants of Caleb.
The sons of Hur, the firstborn son of Ephrath, were Shobal, who first settled Kiriath Jearim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Salma, who first settled Bethlehem, and Hareph, who first settled Beth Gadar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shobal, who first settled Kiriath Jearim, had these descendants: Haroeh, half of the Manahathites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the families of Kiriath Jearim, the Ithrites, the Puthites, the Shumathites, and the Mishraites. From these people came the Zorahites and Eshtaolites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Salma, who first settled Bethlehem, were the Netophathites, Atroth, who first settled Beth Joab, half of the Manahathites, the Zorites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the families of scribes who lived at Jabez. These families were the people of Tira, Shimea, and Sucah. These people are the Kenites who came from Hammath. They first settled Beth Rechab.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were David’s sons who were born to him while he was in Hebron: His first son was Amnon, born to Ahinoam from Jezreel. The second was Daniel, born to Abigail from Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third was Absalom, born to Maacah (the daughter of King Talmai) from Geshur. The fourth was Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth was Shephatiah, born to Abital. The sixth was Ithream, born to David’s wife Eglah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six sons were born to him in Hebron, where he ruled for seven years and six months. He ruled for 33 years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These children were born to David in Jerusalem: Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon (the mother of these four was Ammiel’s daughter Bathshua) and
speaker: Narrator

text: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet (nine by other wives).
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these were David’s sons. Besides these, there were the sons of the concubines. Tamar was their sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s son was Rehoboam. Rehoboam’s son was Abijah. Abijah’s son was Asa. Asa’s son was Jehoshaphat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat’s son was Joram. Joram’s son was Ahaziah. Ahaziah’s son was Joash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash’s son was Amaziah. Amaziah’s son was Azariah. Azariah’s son was Jotham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jotham’s son was Ahaz. Ahaz’s son was Hezekiah. Hezekiah’s son was Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh’s son was Amon. Amon’s son was Josiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Josiah’s firstborn son was Johanan, the second was Jehoiakim, the third was Zedekiah, and the fourth was Shallum.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiakim’s son was Jeconiah, whose son was Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of the prisoner Jeconiah were his son Shealtiel,
speaker: Narrator

text: then Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pedaiah’s sons were Zerubbabel and Shimei. Zerubbabel’s sons were Meshullam and Hananiah, and Shelomith was their sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were also five other sons: Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, and Jushab Hesed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hananiah’s sons were Pelatiah and Jeshaiah. Jeshaiah’s son was Rephaiah. Rephaiah’s son was Arnan. Arnan’s son was Obadiah. Obadiah’s son was Shecaniah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shecaniah’s son was Shemaiah. Shemaiah’s six sons were Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neariah’s three sons were Elioenai, Hizkiah, and Azrikam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elioenai’s seven sons were Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah’s descendants were Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reaiah, son of Shobal, was the father of Jahath. Jahath was the father of Ahumai and Lahad. These were the families of the Zorathites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the first settlers in Etam: Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash. Their sister’s name was Hazelelponi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Penuel was the father of Gedor, and Ezer was the father of Hushah. These were the sons of Hur, the firstborn of Ephrathah, who first settled Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ashhur, who first settled Tekoa, had two wives, Helah and Naarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naarah gave birth to Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari. These were Naarah’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Helah’s sons were Zereth, Izohar, and Ethnan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Koz was the father of Anub and Zobebah, and he was the ancestor of the families of Aharhel, son of Harum.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jabez was more honorable than his brothers. His mother had named him Jabez [Painful], because she said that his birth was painful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jabez prayed to the Elohim of Israel, “Please bless me and give me more territory. May your power be with me and free me from evil so that I will not be in pain.” Elohim gave him what he prayed for.
speaker: Narrator

text: Chelub, Shuhah’s brother, was the father of Mehir, who was the father of Eshton.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eshton was the first to settle Beth Rapha. He was the father of Paseah and Tehinnah, who first settled the city of Nahash. These were the men from Recah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenaz’s sons were Othniel and Seraiah. The sons of Othniel were Hathath and Meonothai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meonothai was the father of Ophrah. Seraiah was the father of Joab, who first settled the valley of Craftsmen. (It was named this because they were craftsmen.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Caleb, son of Jephunneh, were Iru, Elah, and Naam. Elah’s son was Kenaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehallelel’s sons were Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezrah’s sons were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. His wife gave birth to Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah, who first settled Eshtemoa.
speaker: Narrator

text: His Judean wife was the mother of Jered, who first settled Gedor, Heber, who first settled Soco, and Jekuthiel, who first settled Zanoah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Hodiah’s wife, the sister of Naham, first settled Keilah of the Garmites and Eshtemoa of the Maacathites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimon’s sons were Amnon, Rinnah, Ben Hanan, and Tilon. Ishi’s sons were Zoheth and Ben Zoheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shelah, son of Judah, were Er, who first settled Lecah, Laadah, who first settled Mareshah, families of the guild of linen workers at Beth Ashbea,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokim, Joash, Saraph, and the men of Cozeba. Saraph ruled Moab and Jashubi Lehem (according to ancient records).
speaker: Narrator

text: They were the potters who lived at Netaim and Gederah. They lived there with the king and did his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Simeon’s sons were Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, and Shaul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaul’s son was Shallum. Shallum’s son was Mibsam. Mibsam’s son was Mishma.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mishma’s son was Hammuel. Hammuel’s son was Zaccur. Zaccur’s son was Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei had 16 sons and 6 daughters. But his brothers didn’t have many children, so their entire family didn’t become as large as the people of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Simeon’s descendants lived in Beersheba, Moladah, Hazar Shual,
speaker: Narrator

text: Bilhah, Ezem, Tolad,
speaker: Narrator

text: Bethuel, Hormah, Ziklag,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth Marcaboth, Hazar Susim, Beth Biri, and Shaaraim. These were their cities until David became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their five cities were Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also had all the villages around these cities as far as the city of Baal. These places were where they lived, and they had their own genealogical records:
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah (son of Amaziah),
speaker: Narrator

text: Joel, Jehu (son of Joshibiah, grandson of Seraiah, and great-grandson of Asiel),
speaker: Narrator

text: Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah, and
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziza (son of Shiphi, grandson of Allon, great-grandson of Jedaiah, a descendant of Shimri and Shemaiah).
speaker: Narrator

text: These who are mentioned by name were leaders in their families, and the number of people in their households increased.
speaker: Narrator

text: They moved to the outskirts of Gedor, on the east side of the valley, to find pasture for their flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: They found pasture that was rich and good. The land was vast, peaceful, and quiet because the Hamites used to live there.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days of King Hezekiah of Judah, the men listed here knocked down tents and killed the Meunites. They claimed the Meunites for God and destroyed them. (Even today no Meunites live there.) They lived in that land in place of the Meunites in order to have pasture for their flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishi’s sons Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel led 500 of Simeon’s male descendants to Mount Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: They killed the Amalekites who were left. Simeon’s descendants still live there today.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn. (Although he was the firstborn, his rights as firstborn were given to his nephews, Joseph’s sons, because he dishonored his father’s bed. However, Joseph couldn’t be listed in the genealogy as the firstborn son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though Judah was more prominent than his brothers and the prince was to come from him, Joseph received the rights as firstborn.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Reuben, Israel’s firstborn, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joel’s son was Shemaiah. Shemaiah’s son was Gog. Gog’s son was Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei’s son was Micah. Micah’s son was Reaiah. Reaiah’s son was Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baal’s son was Beerah. King Tiglath Pilneser of Assyria took him away as a captive. He was leader of the tribe of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beerah’s brothers according to their families, when they were enrolled in the genealogical records according to their ancestry, were as follows: The first was Jeiel, then Zechariah
speaker: Narrator

text:
and Bela (son of Azaz, grandson of Shema, and great-grandson of Joel).
Reuben’s descendants lived in Aroer as far as Nebo and Baal Meon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of them lived eastward as far as the edge of the desert that extends to the Euphrates River, because they had so much livestock in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Saul’s day they fought a war against the Hagrites, defeated them, and lived in their tents throughout the entire region east of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gad’s descendants lived next to Reuben’s descendants in Bashan as far east as Salcah.
speaker: Narrator

text: One family descended from Gad’s first son Joel. Another family descended from Gad’s second son Shapham. Other families descended from Gad’s sons Janai and Shaphat in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their seven relatives by families were Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Abihail, who was the son of Huri, grandson of Jaroah, and great-grandson of Gilead. Gilead was the son of Michael, grandson of Jeshishai, great-grandson of Jahdo, and great-great-grandson of Buz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahi, son of Abdiel and grandson of Guni, was the head of their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: They lived in Gilead, in Bashan and its villages, and in the entire pastureland of Sharon to its extreme edges.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these people were recorded in genealogical records in the days of King Jotham of Judah and King Jeroboam of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Reuben, Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasseh had 44,760 soldiers ready to go to war. They were skilled fighters who could carry shields and swords and shoot arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to war against Hagar’s descendants (including Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab)
speaker: Narrator

text: and received help while fighting them. Hagar’s descendants and the nations with them were handed over to Reuben’s descendants. They had called out to Elohim during the battle, and he answered their prayers because they trusted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They confiscated the Hagrites’ livestock: 50,000 of their camels, 250,000 sheep and goats, and 2,000 donkeys. They captured 100,000 people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many were killed in battle because this was Elohim’s war. Reuben, Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasseh lived in the Hagrites’ land until the Assyrians captured them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Half of the tribe of Manasseh lived in the land from Bashan to Baal Hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon. The tribe members were numerous.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the heads of Manasseh’s families: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel. They were soldiers who were famous heads of their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Gad, Reuben, and half of the tribe of Manasseh were unfaithful to the Elohim of their ancestors. They chased after the gods of the people of the land as if they were prostitutes. Elohim had destroyed these people as the Israelites arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Elohim of Israel led King Pul of Assyria (King Tiglath Pilneser of Assyria) to take Reuben, Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasseh into captivity. He brought them to Halah, Habor, Hara, and the Gozan River. They are still there today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Levi’s sons were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kohath’s sons were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amram’s children were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. Aaron’s sons were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar was the father of Phinehas. Phinehas was the father of Abishua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishua was the father of Bukki. Bukki was the father of Uzzi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Uzzi was the father of Zerahiah. Zerahiah was the father of Meraioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meraioth was the father of Amariah. Amariah was the father of Ahitub.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahitub was the father of Zadok. Zadok was the father of Ahimaaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimaaz was the father of Azariah. Azariah was the father of Johanan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Johanan was the father of Azariah. (He was the one who served as priest in the temple Solomon built in Jerusalem.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah was the father of Amariah. Amariah was the father of Ahitub.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahitub was the father of Zadok. Zadok was the father of Shallum.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum was the father of Hilkiah. Hilkiah was the father of Azariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah was the father of Seraiah. Seraiah was the father of Jehozadak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehozadak was taken captive when Yahweh used Nebuchadnezzar to take Judah and Jerusalem away into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Levi’s sons were Gershom, Kohath, and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of Gershom’s sons: Libni and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kohath’s sons were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Merari’s sons were Mahli and Mushi.
These are the descendants of Levi’s sons. They are grouped by families:
speaker: Narrator

text: Gershom’s son was Libni. Libni’s son was Jahath. Jahath’s son was Zimmah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zimmah’s son was Joah. Joah’s son was Iddo. Iddo’s son was Zerah. Zerah’s son was Jeatherai.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were Kohath’s descendants: Kohath’s son was Amminadab. Amminadab’s son was Korah. Korah’s son was Assir.
speaker: Narrator

text: Assir’s son was Elkanah. Elkanah’s son was Ebiasaph. Ebiasaph’s son was Assir.
speaker: Narrator

text: Assir’s son was Tahath. Tahath’s son was Uriel. Uriel’s son was Uzziah. Uzziah’s son was Shaul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah’s sons were Amasai and Ahimoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimoth’s son was Elkanah. Elkanah’s son was Zophai. Zophai’s son was Nahath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahath’s son was Eliab. Eliab’s son was Jeroham. Jeroham’s son was Elkanah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel’s sons were Joel, who was his firstborn, and Abijah, who was his second son.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were Merari’s descendants: Merari’s son was Mahli. Mahli’s son was Libni. Libni’s son was Shimei. Shimei’s son was Uzzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Uzzah’s son was Shimea. Shimea’s son was Haggiah. Haggiah’s son was Asaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David put men in charge of the music in Yahweh’s temple after the ark was placed there permanently.
speaker: Narrator

text: They served as musicians in the courtyard in front of the tent of meeting until Solomon built Yahweh’s temple in Jerusalem. They performed their duties according to the regulations set down for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the men who served (their descendants also served):
The musician Heman was from Kohath’s family line. Heman was the son of Joel, who was the son of Samuel,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Elkanah, who was the son of Jeroham, who was the son of Eliel, who was the son of Toah,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Zuph, who was the son of Elkanah, who was the son of Mahath, who was the son of Amasai,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Elkanah, who was the son of Joel, who was the son of Azariah, who was the son of Zephaniah,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Tahath, who was the son of Assir, who was the son of Ebiasaph, who was the son of Korah,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Izhar, who was the son of Kohath, who was the son of Levi, who was the son of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heman’s relative Asaph stood on his right. He was the son of Berechiah, who was the son of Shimea,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Michael, who was the son of Baaseiah, who was the son of Malchiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Ethni, who was the son of Zerah, who was the son of Adaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Ethan, who was the son of Zimmah, who was the son of Shimei,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Jahath, who was the son of Gershom, who was the son of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the left was Ethan, one of Heman’s relatives descended from Merari. Ethan was the son of Kishi, who was the son of Abdi, who was the son of Malluch,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Hashabiah, who was the son of Amaziah, who was the son of Hilkiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Amzi, who was the son of Bani, who was the son of Shemer,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Mahli, who was the son of Mushi, who was the son of Merari, who was the son of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their relatives, the Levites, were assigned all the other duties in the tent, the house of Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron and his descendants offered sacrifices on the altar for burnt offerings and on the altar for incense. They did all the work in the most holy place and removed Israel’s sins to make Israel acceptable to God. They did exactly what Elohim’s servant Moses had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were Aaron’s descendants: His son was Eleazar. Eleazar’s son was Phinehas. Phinehas’ son was Abishua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishua’s son was Bukki. Bukki’s son was Uzzi. Uzzi’s son was Zerahiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zerahiah’s son was Meraioth. Meraioth’s son was Amariah. Amariah’s son was Ahitub.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahitub’s son was Zadok. Zadok’s son was Ahimaaz.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the places where Levi’s descendants lived, the places where they settled in the territory chosen for them when lots were drawn:
The first lot was drawn for the descendants of Aaron from the family descended from Kohath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were given Hebron in the territory of Judah as well as the pastureland around it,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the fields belonging to the city and its villages were given to Caleb, son of Jephunneh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s descendants were given Hebron as a city of refuge, Libnah with its pastureland, Jattir, Eshtemoa with its pastureland,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hilen with its pastureland, Debir with its pastureland,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ashan with its pastureland, and Beth Shemesh with its pastureland.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Benjamin, Aaron’s descendants received Geba with its pastureland, Alemeth with its pastureland, and Anathoth with its pastureland. There was a total of 13 cities for their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Kohath’s descendants received 10 cities chosen by lot from the families of half of the tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families of Gershom’s descendants were given 13 cities chosen by lot from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and the part of the tribe of Manasseh that lived in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The families of Merari’s descendants were given 12 cities chosen by lot from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites gave the Levites the cities with their pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave them the cities chosen by lot and mentioned here by name from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the families of Kohath’s descendants had cities chosen by lot from the tribe of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were given these cities of refuge: Shechem with its pastureland in the hills of Ephraim, Gezer with its pastureland,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokmeam with its pastureland, Beth Horon with its pastureland,
speaker: Narrator

text: Aijalon with its pastureland, and Gath Rimmon with its pastureland.
speaker: Narrator

text: From half of the tribe of Manasseh, they were given Aner with its pastureland and Bileam with its pastureland for the families of the rest of Kohath’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gershom’s descendants received Golan in Bashan with its pastureland and Ashtaroth with its pastureland from the families of half of the tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Issachar, they received Kedesh with its pastureland, Daberath with its pastureland,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ramoth with its pastureland, and Anem with its pastureland.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Asher, they received Mashal with its pastureland, Abdon with its pastureland,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hukok with its pastureland, and Rehob with its pastureland.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Naphtali, they received Kedesh in Galilee with its pastureland, Hammon with its pastureland, and Kiriathaim with its pastureland.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Merari’s descendants received Rimmono with its pastureland and Tabor with its pastureland from the tribe of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Reuben, Merari’s descendants received land east of the Jordan River and across from Jericho: Bezer in the wilderness with its pastureland, Jahzah with its pastureland,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kedemoth with its pastureland and Mephaath with its pastureland.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Gad, they received Ramoth in Gilead with its pastureland, Mahanaim with its pastureland,
speaker: Narrator

text: Heshbon with its pastureland, and Jazer with its pastureland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Issachar’s four sons were Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tola’s sons were Uzzi, Rephaiah, Jeriel, Jahmai, Ibsam, and Shemuel. These men were heads of the families of Tola. They were soldiers grouped according to their ancestry. In David’s day there were 22,600 of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The five descendants of Uzzi were Izrahiah and Izrahiah’s sons Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Isshiah. All of them were heads of families.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had many wives and children. So in addition to these men grouped according to their ancestry and families, there were 36,000 soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their relatives (that is, all of Issachar’s families) were fighting men. A total of 87,000 of them was recorded in the genealogy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benjamin had three sons: Bela, Becher, and Jediael.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bela’s five sons were Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, and Iri. They were heads of families and fighting men. In the genealogy 22,034 of them were recorded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Becher’s sons were Zemirah, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jeremoth, Abijah, Anathoth, and Alemeth. These were all of Becher’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the genealogy 22,200 of them were recorded according to their ancestry (the heads of their families and fighting men).
speaker: Narrator

text: Jediael’s son was Bilhan. Bilhan’s sons were Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Chenaanah, Zethan, Tarshish, and Ahishahar.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these men were Jediael’s descendants. They headed families that produced 17,200 fighting men who could go to war.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Shuppites and Huppites were Ir’s descendants. The Hushites were descendants of someone else.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naphtali’s sons were Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shallum. They were Bilhah’s grandsons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh’s sons were Asriel and Machir. Their mother was Manasseh’s Aramean concubine. Machir was the first to settle Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: He married a wife from the Huppites and Shuppites. His wife’s name was Maacah. The name of his second son was Zelophehad. Zelophehad had only daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Maacah, Machir’s wife, had a son, and she named him Peresh. His brother’s name was Sheresh, whose sons were Ulam and Rakem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ulam’s son was Bedan. These were the people of Gilead, descendants of Machir (son of Manasseh).
speaker: Narrator

text: Bedan’s sister Hammolecheth gave birth to Ishhod, Abiezer, and Mahlah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shemida’s sons were Ahian, Shechem, Likhi, and Aniam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephraim’s son was Shuthelah. Shuthelah’s son was Bered. Bered’s son was Tahath. Tahath’s son was Eleadah. Eleadah’s son was Tahath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tahath’s son was Zabad. Zabad’s son was Shuthelah.
Ephraim’s sons Ezer and Elead were killed by the men of Gath when they came to take their livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father Ephraim mourned a long time, even though his brothers tried to comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he slept with his wife, and she became pregnant. She gave birth to a son, and Ephraim named him Beriah [Tragedy], because tragedy had come to his home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beriah’s daughter was Sheerah, who built Upper and Lower Beth Horon and Uzzen Sheerah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beriah’s son was Rephah. Rephah’s son was Resheph. Resheph’s son was Telah. Telah’s son was Tahan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tahan’s son was Ladan. Ladan’s son was Ammihud. Ammihud’s son was Elishama.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elishama’s son was Nun. Nun’s son was Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land and homes of Ephraim’s descendants were in Bethel and its villages, Naaran to the east, Gezer with its villages to the west, Shechem and its villages, and as far as Gaza and its villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to Manasseh were Beth Shean and its villages, Taanach and its villages, Megiddo and its villages, and Dor and its villages. The descendants of Joseph, son of Israel, live in these cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asher’s sons were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah. Their sister was Serah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beriah’s sons were Heber and Malchiel, who first settled Birzaith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heber was the father of Japhlet, Shomer, Hotham, and their sister Shua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Japhlet’s sons were Pasach, Bimhal, and Ashvath. These were Japhlet’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of his brother Shomer were Rohgah, Jehubbah, and Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brother Helem’s sons were Zophah, Imna, Shelesh, and Amal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zophah’s sons were Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, Imrah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilsha, Ithran, and Beera.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jether’s sons were Jephunneh, Pispa, and Ara.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ulla’s sons were Arah, Hanniel, and Rizia.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these men were Asher’s descendants—heads of their families, outstanding men, soldiers, and distinguished leaders. Their military roster had 26,000 recorded in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benjamin was the father of Bela (his firstborn), Ashbel (his second son), Aharah (his third son),
speaker: Narrator

text: Nohah (his fourth son), and Rapha (his fifth son).
speaker: Narrator

text: Bela’s sons were Addar, Gera, Abihud,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were Ehud’s sons, who were heads of the families living in Geba and who were taken away as captives to Manahath:
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman, Ahijah, and Gera. Gera led the rest of them away as captives. He was the father of Uzza and Ahihud.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaharaim divorced his wives Hushim and Baara. But later in Moab,
speaker: Narrator

text: he and his wife Hodesh had the following sons: Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeuz, Sachia, and Mirmah. All of Shaharaim’s sons became heads of families.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and Hushim were the parents of Abitub and Elpaal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elpaal’s sons were Eber, Misham, and Shemed (who built Ono, Lod, and Lod’s villages).
speaker: Narrator

text: Beriah and Shema were the heads of the families who lived in Aijalon. They forced out the people living in Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their brothers were Shashak and Jeremoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beriah’s sons were Zebadiah, Arad, Eder,
speaker: Narrator

text: Michael, Ishpah, and Joha.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elpaal’s sons were Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, Heber,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmerai, Izliah, and Jobab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei’s sons were Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shashak’s sons were Ishpan, Eber, Eliel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abdon, Zichri, Hanan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Iphdeiah, and Penuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroham’s sons were Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jaareshiah, Elijah, and Zichri.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the heads of families listed by their ancestry. They were the heads of families. They lived in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeiel, who first settled Gibeon, lived in Gibeon, and his wife’s name was Maacah.
speaker: Narrator

text: His firstborn son was Abdon, then Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gedor, Ahio, Zecher,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Mikloth, who was the father of Shimeah. They lived next to their relatives in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ner was the father of Kish. Kish was the father of Saul. Saul was the father of Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan’s son was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal was the father of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Micah’s sons were Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz was the father of Jehoaddah. Jehoaddah was the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri was the father of Moza.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moza was the father of Binea. Binea’s son was Raphah. Raphah’s son was Eleasah. Eleasah’s son was Azel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azel had six sons. Their names were Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. All of these men were Azel’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brother Eshek’s sons were Ulam (the firstborn), Jeush (the second son), and Eliphelet (the third son).
speaker: Narrator

text: Ulam’s sons were soldiers, skilled archers. They had many sons and grandsons, 150 in all. All of these men were Benjamin’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel was recorded in the genealogies in the Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah. The Israelites were taken away to Babylon as captives because they had sinned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first to settle again on their property in their own cities were some Israelites, the priests, the Levites, and the temple servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerusalem was settled by descendants of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh:
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Perez, son of Judah, was Uthai, who was the son of Ammihud, grandson of Omri, and great-grandson of Imri. (Imri’s father was Bani.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Shilah were Asaiah (the firstborn) and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from the descendants of Zerah were Jeuel and their relatives, 690 in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Benjamin were Sallu (son of Meshullam, grandson of Hodaviah, and great-grandson of Hassenuah),
speaker: Narrator

text: Ibneiah (son of Jeroham), Elah (son of Uzzi and grandson of Michri), and Meshullam (son of Shephatiah, grandson of Reuel, and great-grandson of Ibniah),
speaker: Narrator

text: and their relatives according to their ancestry. All of these men were heads of their families. A total of 956 of them lived in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the priests were Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, Jachin,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Azariah. Azariah was the son of Hilkiah, grandson of Meshullam, and great-grandson of Zadok. Zadok’s father was Meraioth, the son of Ahitub (the official in charge of Elohim’s temple).
speaker: Narrator

text: Also from the priests were Adaiah (son of Jeroham, grandson of Pashhur, and great-grandson of Malchiah) and Maasai (son of Adiel, grandson of Jahzerah, and great-grandson of Meshullam, whose father was Meshillemith, son of Immer).
speaker: Narrator

text: Their relatives who were heads of their families totaled 1,760 soldiers. They served in Elohim’s temple and settled in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Levites descended from Merari were Shemaiah (son of Hasshub, grandson of Azrikam, and great-grandson of Hashabiah),
speaker: Narrator

text: Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, Mattaniah (son of Mica, grandson of Zichri, and great-grandson of Asaph),
speaker: Narrator

text: Obadiah (son of Shemaiah, grandson of Galal, and great-grandson of Jeduthun), and Berechiah (son of Asa and grandson of Elkanah, who lived in the villages belonging to the Netophathites).
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeepers were Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives. (Shallum was in charge.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Formerly, they were stationed at the king’s gate on the east side. They were the gatekeepers for the Levite quarters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum (son of Kore, grandson of Ebiasaph, great-grandson of Korah) and the members of his family (Korah’s descendants) were responsible for serving as watchmen at the entrances to the tent, as their ancestors had been in charge of guarding the entrances to Yahweh’s camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Phinehas, Eleazar’s son, had been the official in charge of the gatekeepers, and Yahweh was with him.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah, son of Meshelemiah, was the keeper at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men chosen to be gatekeepers at the entrances totaled 212. Their genealogies were recorded in their villages. David and the seer Samuel appointed them to these positions because they were trustworthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they and their descendants were assigned to be gatekeepers for Yahweh’s house, that is, the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeepers were on the four sides (east, west, north, and south).
speaker: Narrator

text: Their relatives had to come from their villages from time to time. They would come to serve under the gatekeepers’ supervision for a period of seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The four chief Levite gatekeepers were in charge of the rooms and treasures in Elohim’s temple because of their faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: They would spend the night stationed around Elohim’s temple because they had to guard it and open it every morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of them were in charge of the utensils for worship. They would count them when they brought them in and when they took them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Other descendants of Korah were placed in charge of the utensils, the holy utensils, the flour, wine, olive oil, incense, and spices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the priests’ sons prepared the mixture of spices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mattithiah, a Levite, the firstborn son of Shallum, Korah’s descendant, was entrusted with preparing the flat bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of their Kohathite relatives were responsible for setting the bread out in rows every day of worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the musicians who were the heads of the Levite families. They lived in rooms in the temple and were free from other duties because they were on duty day and night.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were the heads of the Levite families according to their ancestry. These head Levites lived in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeiel, who first settled Gibeon, lived in Gibeon, and his wife’s name was Maacah.
speaker: Narrator

text: His firstborn son was Abdon, then Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mikloth was the father of Shimeam. They lived next to their relatives in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ner was the father of Kish. Kish was the father of Saul. Saul was the father of Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan’s son was Meribbaal, and Meribbaal was the father of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Micah’s sons were Pithon, Melech, and Tarea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz was the father of Jarah. Jarah was the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri. Zimri was the father of Moza.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moza was the father of Binea. Binea’s son was Rephaiah. Rephaiah’s son was Eleasah. Eleasah’s son was Azel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azel had six sons. Their names were Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. All of these men were Azel’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines fought against Israel, the men of Israel fled from the Philistines and were killed in battle on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines caught up to Saul and his sons. They killed Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua, Saul’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The heaviest fighting was against Saul. When the archers got him in their range, he was wounded by them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told his armorbearer, “Draw your sword! Stab me, or these godless men will come and make fun of me.” But his armorbearer refused because he was terrified. So Saul took the sword and fell on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the armorbearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on the sword and died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul, his three sons, and his dynasty died together.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people of Israel in the valley saw that their army had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities. So the Philistines came to live in these cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, when the Philistines came to strip the dead, they found Saul and his sons lying on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: They stripped him and took his head and his armor. Then they sent men throughout Philistine territory to tell their idols and the people this good news.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put his armor in the temple of their gods and fastened his head to the temple of Dagon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people of Jabesh Gilead heard about everything the Philistines had done to Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: all the fighting men came and took away the dead bodies of Saul and his sons and brought them to Jabesh. They buried the bones under the oak tree in Jabesh. Then they fasted seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul died because of his unfaithfulness to Yahweh: He did not obey the word of Yahweh. He asked a medium to request information from a dead person.
speaker: Narrator

text: He didn’t request information from Yahweh. So Yahweh killed him and turned the kingship over to David, Jesse’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel gathered around David at Hebron. “We are your own flesh and blood,” they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Even in the past when Saul ruled, you were the one who led Israel on its campaigns to war. Yahweh your Elohim has said to you, ‘You will be shepherd of my people Israel, the leader of my people Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the leaders of Israel had come to Hebron. David made an agreement with them at Hebron in front of Yahweh. So they anointed David king of Israel, as Yahweh had spoken through Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and all Israel went to Jerusalem (that is, Jebus). The Jebusites were living in that region.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told David, “You will never get in here.” But David captured the fortress Zion (that is, the City of David).
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, David said, “Whoever is the first to kill a Jebusite will be made a general and a prince.” Zeruiah’s son Joab was the first to go into Jerusalem, so he became the general.
speaker: Narrator

text: David lived in the fortress, so it was called the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the city of Jerusalem around it, starting from the Millo and making a complete circuit. Joab rebuilt the rest of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: David continued to grow more powerful because Yahweh Tsebaoth was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, these were the commanders of David’s fighting men, who exercised power with him in his kingdom, and with all Israel they made him king according to Yahweh’s word to Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first of David’s fighting men was Jashobeam, son of Hachmon, the leader of the three. He used his spear to kill 300 men on one occasion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next in rank to him was Eleazar, another one of the three fighting men. He was the son of Dodo and grandson of Aho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar was with David at Pas Dammim when the Philistines gathered there for battle. There was a field of ripe barley. When the troops fled from the Philistines,
speaker: Narrator

text: they stood in the middle of the field and defended it by killing Philistines. So Yahweh saved them with an impressive victory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once three of the thirty leading men went down to David’s rock at the cave of Adullam when the army of the Philistines was camping in the valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: While David was in the fortified camp, Philistine troops were in Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was thirsty and said, “I wish I could have a drink of water from the cistern at the city gate of Bethlehem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the three burst into the Philistine camp and drew water from the cistern. They brought it to David, but he refused to drink it. He poured it out as an offering to Yahweh
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, “It’s unthinkable that I would do this, Elohim. Should I drink the blood of these men who risked their lives? They had to risk their lives to get this water.” So he refused to drink it.
These are the things which the three fighting men did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab’s brother Abishai was the leader of the thirty. He used his spear to kill 300 men, but he was not one of the three,
speaker: Narrator

text: although he was honored more than they were. So he became their captain but didn’t become a member of the three.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was from Kabzeel and was a brave man who did many things. He killed two distinguished soldiers from Moab. He also went into a cistern and killed a lion on the day it snowed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He killed an eight-foot-tall Egyptian. The Egyptian had a spear like a weaver’s beam in his hand. But Benaiah went to him with a club, grabbed the spear away from him, and killed him with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the things that Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, did. He was as famous as the three fighting men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was honored more than the thirty, but he was not a member of the three. David put him in charge of his bodyguards.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The distinguished fighting men were
Joab’s brother Asahel,
Elhanan (son of Dodo) from Bethlehem,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shammoth from Harod,
Helez the Pelonite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ira (son of Ikkesh) from Tekoa,
Abiezer from Anathoth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sibbecai (son of Hushai),
Ilai (descendant of Ahohi),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Maharai from Netophah,
Heled (son of Baanah) from Netophah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ithai (son of Ribai) from Gibeah in Benjamin,
Benaiah from Pirathon,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hurai from the Gaash ravines,
Abiel from Beth Arabah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azmaveth from Bahurim,
Eliahba from Shaalbon,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bene Hashem from Gizon,
Jonathan (son of Shage the Hararite),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahiam (son of Sachar the Hararite),
Eliphal (son of Ur),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hepher the Mecherathite,
Ahijah the Pelonite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hezro from Carmel,
Naari (son of Ezbai),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joel (son of Nathan),
Mibhar (son of Hagri),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zelek from Ammon,
Naharai from Beroth, armorbearer for Zeruiah’s son Joab,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ira (descendant of Ithra),
Gareb (descendant of Ithra),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Uriah the Hittite,
Zabad (son of Ahlai),
speaker: Narrator

text: Adina (son of Shiza) from the tribe of Reuben (who was leader of the tribe of Reuben and had his own group of thirty soldiers),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hanan (son of Maacah),
and Joshaphat the Mithnite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Uzzia from Ashteroth,
Shama and Jeiel (sons of Hotham from Aroer),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jediael (son of Shimri) and
his brother Joha the Tizite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eliel the Mahavite,
Jeribai and Joshaviah (sons of Elnaam),
Ithmah from Moab,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eliel,
Obed, and
Jaasiel the Mezobaite.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the men who came to David at Ziklag when he was banished by Saul, son of Kish. They were among the soldiers who went into battle with David.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were armed with bows and could sling stones or shoot arrows with either their right or their left hands. They were Saul’s relatives, from the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahiezer was the leader, then Joash (they were the sons of Shemaah from Gibeah), Azmaveth’s sons Jeziel and Pelet, Beracah and Jehu from Anathoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmaiah from Gibeon (one of the thirty fighting men and one of their leaders), Jeremiah, Jahaziel, Johanan, and Jozabad from Gederah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eluzai, Jerimoth, Bealiah, Shemariah, and Shephatiah from Haruph,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, and Jashobeam (Korah’s descendants),
speaker: Narrator

text: and Joelah and Zebadiah, Jeroham’s sons from Gedor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men left Gad to join David at the fortified camp in the desert. They were warriors, trained soldiers, able to fight with shields and spears. They looked like lions and were as fast as gazelles on the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezer was the first of these soldiers. The second was Obadiah. The third was Eliab.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourth was Mishmannah. The fifth was Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixth was Attai. The seventh was Eliel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eighth was Johanan. The ninth was Elzabad.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tenth was Jeremiah. The eleventh was Machbannai.
speaker: Narrator

text: These descendants of Gad were army officers. The least able one was in command of 100 men, and the best one was in command of 1,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first month of the year, these men crossed the Jordan River when it was flooding its banks. They chased away all the people in the valleys to the east and west.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the men of Benjamin and Judah came to David at the fortified camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went to meet them. He told them, “If you’ve come to help me as friends would, then you may join me. But if you’ve come to betray me to my enemies, even though I haven’t committed a crime, may the Elohim of our ancestors see this and judge you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Ruach gave Amasai, the leader of the thirty, the strength to say,
“We are yours, David.
We are with you, son of Jesse.
    Success, success to you!
    Success to those who help you,
        because your Elohim is helping you.”
So David welcomed them and made them officers over his troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men from Manasseh had deserted Saul’s army to join David when he went with the Philistines to attack Saul. (However, David didn’t help the Philistines because their rulers sent him away after considering the matter. They said, “It will cost us our heads when he deserts and joins his master Saul.”)
speaker: Narrator

text: When David went to Ziklag, these men from Manasseh deserted to join him: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai. Each one was an officer over 1,000 men in Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: They helped David fight raiding parties because they were all warriors, commanders in the army.
speaker: Narrator

text: From day to day, men came to help David until he had an army as large as Elohim’s army.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the numbers of the men equipped for war. The men joined David at Hebron to turn Saul’s kingship over to David, as Yahweh had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Judah’s descendants there were 6,800 men equipped for war. They carried shields and spears.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Simeon’s descendants there were 7,100 warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Levi’s descendants there were 4,600
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as Jehoiada (leader of Aaron’s families). With him there were 3,700 men,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Zadok, a young warrior from whose family came 22 officers.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Benjamin’s descendants, Saul’s relatives, there were 3,000 men, though most of them remained loyal to Saul’s family.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Ephraim’s descendants there were 20,800 warriors who were famous among their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: From half of the tribe of Manasseh there were 18,000 who had been designated by name to make David king.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Issachar’s descendants there were 200 leaders who understood the times and knew what Israel should do. Their relatives were under their command.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Zebulun there were 50,000 experienced soldiers. They were equipped for battle with every kind of weapon. Their loyalty was unquestioned.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Naphtali there were 1,000 commanders. With them were 37,000 who fought with shields and spears.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Dan there were 28,600 ready for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Asher there were 40,000 experienced soldiers ready for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the east side of the Jordan River, from Reuben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasseh, there were 120,000 soldiers ready to fight with all kinds of weapons.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these soldiers, who were prepared for battle, came with a single purpose to Hebron—to make David king of all Israel. The rest of Israel also had agreed to make David king.
speaker: Narrator

text: They ate and drank with David for three days because their relatives in Judah had provided enough for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, their neighbors as far as the territories of Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali brought food on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen. There was plenty of flour, fig cakes, raisins, wine, olive oil, cattle, and sheep, because Israel was celebrating.
speaker: Narrator

text: David consulted with every officer who commanded a regiment or battalion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told the whole assembly of Israel, “If you approve and if Yahweh our Elohim has consented, we will send an invitation to the rest of our relatives in every region of Israel and to the priests and Levites in their cities and pasturelands so that they may join us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we’ll bring back our Elohim’s ark, which we ignored while Saul was king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole assembly agreed to this because the people considered it the right thing to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David gathered all Israel from the Shihor River near Egypt to the border of Hamath in order to bring Elohim’s ark from Kiriath Jearim.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and all Israel went to Baalah in Kiriath Jearim, which is in Judah, to bring Elohim’s ark to Jerusalem. (Yahweh is enthroned over the angels on the ark where his name is used.)
speaker: Narrator

text: David and his men put Elohim’s ark on a new cart from Abinadab’s home. Uzzah and Ahio guided the cart.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and all Israel were celebrating in Elohim’s presence with all their might, with songs, with lyres, harps, tambourines, cymbals, and trumpets.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they came to Chidon’s threshing floor, the oxen stumbled. So Uzzah reached out to grab the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh became angry with Uzzah and killed him for reaching for the ark. He died in Elohim’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was angry because Yahweh had struck Uzzah so violently. (That place is still called Perez Uzzah [The Striking of Uzzah] today.)
speaker: Narrator

text: David was afraid of Elohim that day. “How can I bring Elohim’s ark to my city?” he asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he didn’t bring God’s ark to his home, the City of David. Instead, he rerouted it to the home of Obed Edom, who was from Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elohim’s ark stayed at the home of Obed Edom with his family for three months, and Yahweh blessed Obed Edom’s family and everything he owned.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to David, along with cedarwood, masons, and carpenters to build a palace for David.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David realized that Yahweh had established him as king of Israel and that his kingdom was made famous for the sake of Israel, Yahweh’s people.
speaker: Narrator

text: David married more wives in Jerusalem and fathered more sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the children who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elishama, Beeliada, and Eliphelet.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king of Israel, all of them came to attack David. But David heard about it and went out to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines had come and raided the valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David asked Elohim, “Should I attack the Philistines? Will you hand them over to me?”
Yahweh answered him, “Attack! I will hand them over to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men attacked and defeated the Philistines at Baal Perazim. David said, “Using my power like an overwhelming flood, Elohim has overwhelmed my enemies.” That is why they call that place Baal Perazim [The Lord Overwhelms].
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines left their gods there, so David ordered that the gods be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines again raided the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once more David asked Elohim.
Elohim answered him, “Don’t go after them. Circle around, and come at them in front of the balsam trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: As you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then go out and fight because Elohim has gone ahead of you to defeat the Philistine army.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David did as Elohim ordered him, and his men defeated the Philistine army from Gibeon to Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s fame spread through all lands, and Yahweh made all the nations fear him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After David constructed buildings for himself in the City of David, he prepared a place for Elohim’s ark and set up a tent for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David insisted that only the Levites carry Elohim’s ark because Yahweh had chosen them to carry Yahweh’s ark and to serve him forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: David called together all Israel at Jerusalem to bring Yahweh’s ark to the place he had prepared for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also called together Aaron’s descendants and the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leading Kohath’s descendants was Uriel, who came with 120 of his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leading Merari’s descendants was Asaiah, who came with 220 of his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leading Gershom’s descendants was Joel, who came with 130 of his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leading Elizaphan’s descendants was Shemaiah, who came with 200 of his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leading Hebron’s descendants was Eliel, who came with 80 of his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leading Uzziel’s descendants was Amminadab, who came with 112 of his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: David called for the priests Zadok and Abiathar and for the Levites Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “You are the heads of the Levite families. You and your relatives must perform the ceremonies to make yourselves holy. Then bring the ark of Yahweh Elohim of Israel to the place I prepared for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you weren’t there the first time, Yahweh our Elohim struck us. We hadn’t dedicated our lives to serving him in the way he designated.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priests and the Levites made themselves holy in order to move the ark of Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites carried Elohim’s ark on their shoulders. They used poles as Moses had commanded according to Yahweh’s instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told the Levite leaders to appoint some of their relatives to serve as musicians. They were expected to play music on harps, lyres, and cymbals to produce joyful music for singing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Levites appointed Heman, son of Joel, and from his relatives they appointed Asaph, Berechiah’s son. From their own relatives, Merari’s descendants, they appointed Ethan, son of Kushaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition, they appointed their relatives from the second division: Zechariah, Jaaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, and Mikneiah. Obed Edom and Jeiel were appointed gatekeepers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The musicians Heman, Asaph, and Ethan were appointed to play bronze cymbals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah, Jaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah were appointed to play harps according to alamoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed Edom, Jeiel, and Azaziah were appointed to play lyres and to conduct the sheminith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Chenaniah, a Levite leader, instructed others how to sing prophetic songs because he was skilled at it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Berechiah and Elkanah were gatekeepers for the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests Shebaniah, Joshaphat, Nethanel, Amasai, Zechariah, Benaiah, and Eliezer blew trumpets in front of Elohim’s ark. Obed Edom and Jehiah were doorkeepers for the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David, the leaders of Israel, and the army’s commanders joyfully went to get the ark of Yahweh’s promise from Obed Edom’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because Elohim helped the Levites who carried the ark of Yahweh’s promise, they sacrificed seven bulls and seven rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was dressed in a fine linen robe, as were all the Levites who carried the ark, the Levites who were singers, and Chenaniah, the leader of the musicians’ prophetic songs. David also wore a linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel brought the ark of Yahweh’s promise with shouts of joy and the sounding of rams’ horns, trumpets, cymbals, harps, and lyres.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ark of Yahweh’s promise came to the City of David, Saul’s daughter Michal looked out of a window and saw King David dancing and celebrating, so she despised him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men carrying the ark set it inside the tent David had put up for it. They presented burnt offerings and fellowship offerings in Elohim’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had finished sacrificing burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, he blessed the people in the name of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also distributed to every person in Israel—both men and women—a loaf of bread, a date cake, and a raisin cake.
speaker: Narrator

text: David appointed some Levites to serve in front of Yahweh’s ark by offering prayers, thanks, and praise to Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asaph was the head; Zechariah was second, then Jeiel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, Obed Edom, and Jeiel with harps and lyres. Asaph played the cymbals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests Benaiah and Jahaziel played trumpets all the time in front of the ark of Elohim’s promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the first time David entrusted Asaph and his relatives with the task of singing songs of thanks to Yahweh:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Give thanks to Yahweh.
Call on his name.
Make known among the nations what he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing to him.
Make music to praise him.
Meditate on all the miracles he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Brag about his holy name.
Let the hearts of those who seek Yahweh rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Search for Yahweh and his strength.
Always seek his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember the miracles he performed,
    the amazing things he did and the judgments he pronounced,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you descendants of Israel, his servant,
    you descendants of Jacob, his chosen ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He is Yahweh our Elohim.
    His judgments are pronounced throughout the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember his promise forever,
    the word that he commanded for a thousand generations,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the promise that he made to Abraham,
    and his sworn promise to Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He confirmed it as a law for Jacob,
    as an everlasting promise to Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
by saying, ‘I will give you Canaan.
    It is your share of the inheritance.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“While they were few in number,
    a small group of foreigners living in that land,
speaker: Narrator

text:
they wandered from nation to nation
    and from one kingdom to another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He didn’t permit anyone to oppress them.
He warned kings about them:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Do not touch my anointed ones
    or harm my prophets.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Sing to Yahweh, all the earth!
    Day after day announce that Yahweh saves his people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell people about his glory.
    Tell all the nations about his miracles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yahweh is great!
    He should be highly praised.
    He should be feared more than all other gods
speaker: Narrator

text:
because all the gods of the nations are idols.
Yahweh made the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Splendor and majesty are in his presence.
Strength and joy are where he is.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Give to Yahweh, you families of the nations.
Give to Yahweh glory and power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give to Yahweh the glory his name deserves.
    Bring an offering, and come to him.
        Worship Yahweh in his holy splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tremble in his presence, all the earth!
“The earth stands firm; it cannot be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the heavens rejoice and the earth be glad.
    Say to the nations, ‘Yahweh rules as king!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the sea and everything in it roar like thunder.
    Let the fields and everything in them rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the trees in the forest will sing with joy
    in the presence of Yahweh when he comes to judge the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Give thanks to Yahweh because he is good,
    because his mercy endures forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say, ‘Rescue us, O Elohim our Savior.
    Gather us and save us from the nations
        so that we may give thanks to your holy name
            and make your praise our glory.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thanks be to Yahweh Elohim of Israel
    from everlasting to everlasting.”
Then all the people said amen and praised Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: David left Asaph and his relatives to serve continually in front of the ark of Yahweh’s promise, as the daily work required.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also left Obed Edom and 68 of his relatives to serve there. Obed Edom (Jeduthun’s son) and Hosah were to be gatekeepers.
speaker: Narrator

text: David left Zadok and his priestly relatives to serve in Yahweh’s tent at the place of worship in Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were ordered to sacrifice burnt offerings to Yahweh. This happened on the altar of burnt offerings continually, morning and evening, as written in Yahweh’s Teachings that he gave Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: With Zadok and his relatives were Heman, Jeduthun, and the rest of the Levites who had been selected, chosen by name, to give thanks to Yahweh by singing, “His mercy endures forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, Heman and Jeduthun played trumpets, cymbals, and the other musical instruments that accompany sacred songs. Jeduthun’s sons were stationed at the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people went home. David went back to bless his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was living in his house, he said to the prophet Nathan, “I’m living in a house made of cedar, while the ark of Yahweh’s promise is inside a tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan told David, “Do everything you have in mind, because Elohim is with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But that same night Elohim spoke his word to Nathan:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to David, my servant, ‘This is what Yahweh says: You must not build this house for me to live in.
speaker: Narrator

text: I haven’t lived in a house from the day I brought Israel out of Egypt to this day, but I’ve gone from tent site to tent site, moving the tent of meeting from one location to another.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all the places I’ve moved with all Israel, did I ever ask any of the judges of Israel whom I ordered to be shepherds of my people why they didn’t build me a house of cedar?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now this is what you will say to my servant David: ‘This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth says: I took you from the pasture where you followed sheep so that you could be the leader of my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was with you wherever you went, and I destroyed all your enemies in front of you. I will make your name like the names of the greatest people on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make a place for my people Israel and plant them there. They will live in their own place and not be troubled anymore. The wicked will no longer frighten them as they used to do
speaker: Narrator

text: ever since I appointed judges to rule my people Israel. I will crush all your enemies. I even tell you that I, Yahweh, will build a house for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘When the time comes for you to go and be with your ancestors, I will send one of your descendants. He will be one of your sons. I will establish his kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will build a house for me, and I will establish his throne forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be his Ab, and he will be my Son. And I will never stop showing him my love as I did to your predecessor.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will place him in my royal house forever, and his throne will be established forever.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan told David all these words and everything he had seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King David went into the tent and sat in front of Yahweh. “Who am I, Yahweh Elohim,” he asked, “and why is my house so important that you have brought me this far?
speaker: Narrator
