text: And this you consider to be a small act, Elohim. You’ve spoken about the distant future of my house. Yahweh Elohim, you’ve shown me the generation of the great man.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What more can I do for you in light of the honor you have given to me and since you know me so well!
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh, you’ve done this great thing for my sake and your own desire. You made this great thing known to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yahweh, there is no one like you, and there is no other god except you, as we have heard with our own ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is like your people Israel? It is the one nation on earth that Elohim came to free in order to make its people his own, to make your name known, and to do great and wonderful things for them. You forced the nations and their gods out of the way of your people, whom you freed from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You made the people of Israel to be your people forever. And you, Yahweh, became their Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, Yahweh, faithfully keep the promise you made to me and my house forever. Do as you promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your name will endure and be respected forever when people say, ‘Yahweh Tsebaoth, the Elohim of Israel, is Israel’s Elohim.’ And the house of David, your servant, will be established in your presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: You, my Elohim, have revealed especially to me that you will build me a house. That is why I have found the courage to pray to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yahweh, you are Elohim. You promised me this good thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, you were pleased to bless my house so that it may continue in your presence forever. Indeed, you, Yahweh, have blessed it. It will be blessed forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, David defeated and crushed the Philistines. He took Gath and its surrounding villages from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also defeated Moab, and the Moabites became David’s subjects and paid taxes to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David went to establish his control over the territory along the Euphrates River, he defeated King Hadadezer at Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took 1,000 chariots, 7,000 horsemen, and 20,000 foot soldiers from him. David also disabled all but 100 of their horses so that they couldn’t pull chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Arameans from Damascus came to help King Hadadezer of Zobah, David killed 22,000 of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: David put troops in the Aramean kingdom of Damascus, and the Arameans became his subjects and paid taxes to him. Everywhere David went, Yahweh gave him victories.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the gold shields that Hadadezer’s servants carried, and he brought them to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also took a large quantity of bronze from Tibhath and Cun, Hadadezer’s cities. (Later Solomon used it to make the pool, pillars, and utensils for the temple.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Tou of Hamath heard that David had defeated the whole army of Zobah’s King Hadadezer,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent his son Hadoram to greet King David and congratulate him for fighting and defeating Hadadezer. (There had often been war between Hadadezer and Tou.)
speaker: Narrator

text: King David dedicated all the articles of gold, silver, and bronze to Yahweh, along with the silver and gold he had taken from other nations—from Edom, Moab, Ammon, the Philistines, and Amalek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zeruiah’s son Abishai killed 18,000 Edomites in the Dead Sea region.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put troops in Edom, and all its people became David’s subjects. Everywhere David went, Yahweh gave him victories.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David ruled all Israel. He did what was fair and right for all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zeruiah’s son Joab was in charge of the army. Ahilud’s son Jehoshaphat was the royal historian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahitub’s son Zadok and Abiathar’s son Abimelech were priests. Shavsha was the royal scribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada’s son Benaiah was commander of the Cherethites and the Pelethites. And David’s sons were his main officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later King Nahash of Ammon died, and his son became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: David thought, “I will show kindness to Hanun because his father Nahash showed me kindness.” So David sent messengers to comfort Hanun after his father’s death. But when David’s servants entered Ammonite territory to comfort Hanun,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Ammonite princes asked Hanun, “Do you think David is honoring your father because he sent men to comfort you? Haven’t his servants come to explore, destroy, and spy on the country?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hanun took David’s men, shaved them, cut off their clothes from the waist down, and sent them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: After people told David what had happened to the men, he sent someone to meet them because they were deeply humiliated. The king said to them, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return to Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites realized that they had made themselves offensive to David. So Hanun and the Ammonites sent 75,000 pounds of silver to hire chariots and horses from the Arameans in Upper Mesopotamia, Maacah, and Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They hired 32,000 chariots and the king of Maacah with his army. They camped near Medeba. The Ammonites gathered for the battle from their cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: After David heard about this, he sent Joab and all the elite troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites formed a battle line at the entrance of the city, while the Arameans from Zobah and Rehob and the kings who had come remained by themselves in the open country.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab saw he was under attack in front and behind, he took the select troops of Israel and organized them for combat against the Arameans.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put his brother Abishai in charge of the rest of the troops. They organized for combat against the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said, “If the Arameans are too strong for my troops, be ready to help me. And if the Ammonites are too strong for your troops, I’ll help you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong! Let’s prove ourselves strong for our people and for the cities of our Elohim, and Yahweh will do what he considers right.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab and his troops advanced to fight the Arameans, and the Arameans fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they, too, fled from Joab’s brother Abishai and went into the city. So Joab returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Realizing that Israel had defeated them, the kings sent messengers to get other Arameans from beyond the Euphrates River. Shophach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army, led them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was told about this, he assembled Israel’s army, crossed the Jordan, and confronted them. David formed a battle line against the Arameans, and they fought him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Arameans fled from Israel, and David killed 7,000 chariot drivers and 40,000 foot soldiers. David also killed Shophach.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the kings who were subject to Hadadezer saw that Israel had defeated them, they made peace with David and became his subjects. And the Arameans were no longer willing to help the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the spring, the time when kings go out to battle, Joab led the army to war. They destroyed the Ammonites and came to Rabbah to attack it, while David stayed in Jerusalem. Joab defeated Rabbah and tore it down.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the gold crown from the head of Rabbah’s king and put it on David’s head. (The crown was found to weigh 75 pounds, and in it was a precious stone.) David also took a lot of goods from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought out the troops who were there and put them to work with saws, hoes, and axes. He did the same to all the Ammonite cities. Then David and all the troops returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, war broke out with the Philistines at Gezer. Then Sibbecai from Hushah killed Sippai, a descendant of Haraphah, and the Philistines were defeated.
speaker: Narrator

text: When more fighting broke out with the Philistines, Elhanan, son of Jair, killed Lahmi, the brother of Goliath from Gath. (The shaft of Lahmi’s spear was like a beam used by weavers.)
speaker: Narrator

text: In another battle at Gath, there was a tall man who had 24 fingers and toes: six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot. He also was a descendant of Haraphah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he challenged Israel, Jonathan, son of David’s brother Shimea, killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men were the descendants of Haraphah from Gath, and David and his men killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Satan attempted to attack Israel by provoking David to count the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Joab and the leaders of the people, “Go, count Israel from Beersheba to Dan. Bring me the results so that I may know how many people there are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab responded, “May Yahweh multiply his people a hundred times over. But, Your Majesty, aren’t they all your servants? Why are you trying to do this? Why do you wish to make Israel guilty of this sin?”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the king overruled Joab. So Joab left, went throughout Israel, and returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab reported the census figures to David: In Israel there were 1,100,000 men who could serve in the army, and in Judah there were 470,000 who could serve in the army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab didn’t include Levi and Benjamin in the number because he was disgusted with the king’s order.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elohim considered the census to be sinful, so he struck Israel with a plague.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Elohim, “I have committed a terrible sin by doing this thing. Forgive me because I have acted very foolishly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Gad, David’s seer.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and tell David, ‘This is what Yahweh says: I’m offering you three choices. Choose the one you want me to do to you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gad came to David, he said, “This is what Yahweh says: ‘Take your pick:
speaker: Narrator

text: either three years of famine, or three months during which your enemies will chase you away when their swords catch up to you, or three days of Yahweh’s sword—a plague in the land with the Messenger of Yahweh destroying the whole country of Israel.’ Decide what answer I should give the one who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m in a desperate situation,” David told Gad. “Please let me fall into Yahweh’s hands because he is extremely merciful. But don’t let me fall into human hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh sent a plague on Israel, and 70,000 Israelites died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elohim also sent a Messenger to Jerusalem to destroy it, but as he was destroying it, Yahweh reconsidered and changed his mind about the disaster. “Enough!” he said to the destroying Messenger. “Put down your weapon.” The Messenger of Yahweh was standing by the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David looked up, he saw the Messenger of Yahweh standing between heaven and earth. The Messenger had a sword in his hand and stretched it over Jerusalem. David and the leaders were dressed in sackcloth. They bowed down with their faces touching the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Elohim, “I’m the one who ordered the people to be counted. I am the one who sinned and did wrong. What have these sheep done? Yahweh my Elohim, let your punishment be against me and my father’s family, but don’t punish your people with a plague.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh’s Messenger told Gad to tell David to go and set up an altar for Yahweh at Ornan the Jebusite’s threshing floor.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went as Gad had told him in Yahweh’s name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, Ornan had turned around and seen the Messenger. Ornan’s four sons who were with him hid, but Ornan kept on threshing the wheat.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David arrived, Ornan looked up and saw him. So he left the threshing floor and bowed down with his face touching the ground in front of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Ornan, “Let me have the land this threshing floor is on. I’ll build an altar for Yahweh on it. Sell it to me for the full price. Then the plague on the people will stop.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ornan said to David, “Take it, Your Majesty, and do whatever you think is right. I’ll give you oxen for the burnt offering, threshers for firewood, and wheat for the grain offering. I’ll give you everything.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No,” King David told Ornan, “I insist on buying it for the full price. I won’t take what is yours for Yahweh and offer burnt sacrifices that cost me nothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David gave Ornan 15 pounds of gold for that place.
speaker: Narrator

text: David built an altar for Yahweh there and sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. He called on Yahweh, and Yahweh answered him by sending fire from heaven on the altar for burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh spoke to the Messenger, and he put his sword back in its scabbard.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, when David saw Yahweh had answered him at the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite, he offered sacrifices there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh’s tent that Moses made in the desert and the altar for burnt offerings were at the worship site at Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, David couldn’t go there to consult Elohim because he was frightened by the sword of Yahweh’s Messenger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said, “This is where Yahweh Elohim’s temple will be. Israel’s altar for burnt offerings will also be here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David ordered the foreigners living in Israel to gather. He appointed some of them to cut stones to build Elohim’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: David prepared a large quantity of iron for nails and fittings on the doors of the gates. He also prepared so much bronze that it couldn’t be weighed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Sidon and Tyre brought David so many cedar logs that the logs couldn’t be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: David thought, “My son Solomon is young and inexperienced, and the temple that will be built for Yahweh must be magnificent, large, famous, praised, and honored in all other countries. I’ll prepare the building materials for him.” So David prepared many materials for Solomon before he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: He summoned his son Solomon and commanded him to build a temple for Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told his son Solomon, “I had my heart set on building a temple for the name of Yahweh, my Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Yahweh spoke his word to me by saying, ‘You have caused a lot of bloodshed and fought in a lot of wars. You must not build a temple for my name because you have caused so much bloodshed in my presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have a son who will be a peaceful man. I will give him peace from all the enemies around him. His name will be Solomon [Peace], and in his time I will give Israel peace and quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will build a temple for my name. He will be my son, and I will be his Ab. I will establish the throne of his kingdom permanently over Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: David continued, “Now, son, Yahweh will be with you. You will be successful, and you will build the temple of Yahweh your Elohim as he predicted you would.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh will give you insight and understanding as he commands you to take charge of Israel and to follow the Teachings of Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will succeed if you will carefully obey the laws and decrees Yahweh commanded Moses to give to Israel. Be strong and courageous. Don’t be afraid or terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Despite my troubles I’ve made preparations for Yahweh’s temple. There are 7,500,000 pounds of gold, 75,000,000 pounds of silver, and so much bronze and iron that it can’t be weighed. I’ve also prepared wood and stones, and you may add to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have many kinds of workers: stonecutters, masons, carpenters, and men skilled in every kind of work.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold, silver, bronze, and iron are more than can be counted. So get to work! May Yahweh be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David ordered all the leaders of Israel to help his son Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “Isn’t Yahweh your Elohim with you? Hasn’t he given you peace with all your neighbors? He put the people who live in this country under my power, and the country has been conquered by Yahweh and his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So dedicate your hearts and lives to serving Yahweh your Elohim. Start building the holy place of Yahweh Elohim so that you can bring the ark of Yahweh’s promise and Elohim’s holy utensils into the temple that will be built for Yahweh’s name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had grown old and had lived out his years, he made his son Solomon king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gathered all the officials of Israel and the priests and Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every male Levite who was at least 30 years old was counted. There were 38,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of these, 24,000 were appointed to supervise the work on Yahweh’s temple, 6,000 were appointed to be officers and judges,
speaker: Narrator

text: 4,000 were appointed to be gatekeepers, and 4,000 were appointed to praise Yahweh with the instruments David had made for praising God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David organized the Levites into divisions based on which of Levi’s sons (Gershon, Kohath, or Merari) they were descended from.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ladan and Shimei were Gershon’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ladan had three sons: Jehiel was the first, then Zetham, and Joel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei had three sons: Shelomith, Haziel, and Haran. They were the heads of Ladan’s families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei’s sons were Jahath, Zina, Jeush, and Beriah. They were Shimei’s four sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahath was the first, and Ziza was the second. Jeush and Beriah didn’t have many sons, so they were given an assignment as one family.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kohath had four sons: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amram’s sons were Aaron and Moses. Aaron and his sons were forever designated to dedicate the most holy things to God, to offer sacrifices to Yahweh, to serve him, and always give the blessing in his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Moses, the man of Elohim, were counted with the tribe of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ sons were Gershom and Eliezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gershom’s only son was Shebuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliezer’s only son was Rehabiah. Eliezer had no other sons, but Rehabiah had many sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Izhar’s only son was Shelomith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hebron’s first son was Jeriah; his second was Amariah; his third was Jahaziel; his fourth was Jekameam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Uzziel’s first son was Micah; his second was Isshiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Merari’s sons were Mahli and Mushi. Mahli’s sons were Eleazar and Kish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar died without having any sons. He only had daughters. Their cousins, the sons of Kish, married them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mushi had three sons: Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were Levi’s descendants, who were grouped according to their families. The heads of their families were registered by name as they were counted. Everyone who served in Yahweh’s temple was at least 20 years old.
speaker: Narrator

text: David had said, “Yahweh Elohim of Israel has given his people rest. He will now live in Jerusalem forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites will no longer have to carry the tent and all the utensils used in worship.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s last instructions were to count the Levites who were at least 20 years old.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were appointed to stand beside Aaron’s descendants to serve in Yahweh’s temple. They were appointed to be in charge of the courtyards and the temple rooms, to ensure that all the holy things were clean, and to serve in Elohim’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were also responsible for the rows of bread, the flour for the grain offerings, the unleavened bread wafers, and the bread made in frying pans. In addition, they were responsible for mixing the ingredients and keeping track of all weights and measures.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were appointed to stand to give thanks and praise to Yahweh every morning. They were appointed to do the same thing in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were appointed to stand in front of Yahweh in the required numbers whenever burnt offerings were made—on weekly worship days, at New Moon Festivals, and on appointed annual festivals.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were appointed to follow the regulations for the tent of meeting and the holy place and to help their relatives, Aaron’s descendants, as they served in Yahweh’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The divisions of Aaron’s descendants were as follows: Aaron’s sons were Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab and Abihu died before their father died, and neither had any children. So Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: David, Eleazar’s descendant Zadok, and Ithamar’s descendant Ahimelech divided Aaron’s descendants into groups for service.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since Eleazar’s descendants had more men who were family heads than Ithamar’s descendants, they were divided so that Eleazar’s descendants had 16 family leaders and Ithamar’s descendants had 8 family leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both groups were divided impartially by drawing lots so that there were officers for the holy place and officers for Elohim among both Eleazar’s and Ithamar’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: The scribe Shemaiah was a son of Nethanel and a descendant of Levi. Shemaiah recorded their names in the presence of the king, the princes, the priest Zadok, Ahimelech (son of Abiathar), and the family leaders of the priests and Levites. One family was chosen for Eleazar, another for Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first lot drawn was for Jehoiarib, the second for Jedaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the third for Harim, the fourth for Seorim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifth for Malchiah, the sixth for Mijamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the seventh for Hakkoz, the eighth for Abijah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the ninth for Jeshua, the tenth for Shecaniah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the eleventh for Eliashib, the twelfth for Jakim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the thirteenth for Huppah, the fourteenth for Jeshebeab,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifteenth for Bilgah, the sixteenth for Immer,
speaker: Narrator

text: the seventeenth for Hezir, the eighteenth for Happizzez,
speaker: Narrator

text: the nineteenth for Pethahiah, the twentieth for Jehezkel,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-first for Jachin, the twenty-second for Gamul,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-third for Delaiah, the twenty-fourth for Maaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were their priestly groups when they went to serve at Yahweh’s temple. Their ancestor Aaron made these rules for them, as Yahweh Elohim of Israel had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The following men were leaders for Levi’s descendants from Kohath:
Jehdeiah (for Amram’s descendants through Shubael),
speaker: Narrator

text: Isshiah (for Amram’s descendants through Rehabiah),
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahath (for Izhar’s descendants through Shelomoth),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jeriah (for Hebron’s descendants),
Amariah (the second of Hebron’s descendants),
Jahaziel (the third of Hebron’s descendants),
Jekameam (the fourth of Hebron’s descendants),
speaker: Narrator

text: Shamir (for Uzziel’s descendants through Micah),
speaker: Narrator

text: and Zechariah (for Uzziel’s descendants through Micah’s brother Isshiah).
speaker: Narrator

text:
The following men were leaders from Levi’s descendants from Merari:
Mahli, Mushi, and Merari’s son Jaaziah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri (for Merari’s descendants through his son Jaaziah),
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar (who had no sons, for Mahli’s descendants),
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerahmeel (for Mahli’s descendants through Kish),
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth (for Mushi’s descendants).
These were Levi’s descendants according to their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: They drew lots as their relatives, Aaron’s descendants, had done. They drew them in front of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the leaders of the families of the priests and Levites. The families of the oldest brother were treated the same way as those of the youngest.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and the army commanders appointed the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun to serve as prophets with lyres, harps, and cymbals. This is the list of the men who performed this service:
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Asaph were Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asharelah. (They were directed by Asaph, who served as a prophet under the king’s direction.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Jeduthun were Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah, Mattithiah. (The six brothers were directed by their father, the prophet Jeduthun. They thanked and praised Yahweh as they played lyres.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Heman were Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamti Ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: (All of them were the sons of the king’s seer Heman. They were given to him to make him prominent, as Elohim had promised. So Elohim gave Heman 14 sons and 3 daughters.)
speaker: Narrator

text: All these Levites sang at Yahweh’s temple under the direction of their fathers Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman. They played cymbals, lyres, and harps for worship in Elohim’s temple under the direction of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: They, along with their relatives, were trained, skilled musicians for Yahweh. There were 288 of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They drew lots for their assignment of duties, the youngest as well as the oldest, the skilled musicians along with the students.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The first lot drawn chose Joseph, the son of Asaph.
The second chose Gedaliah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third chose Zaccur, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourth chose Izri, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth chose Nethaniah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixth chose Bukkiah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventh chose Jesarelah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eighth chose Jeshaiah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ninth chose Mattaniah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tenth chose Shimei, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eleventh chose Azarel, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twelfth chose Hashabiah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The thirteenth chose Shubael, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourteenth chose Mattithiah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifteenth chose Jeremoth, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixteenth chose Hananiah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventeenth chose Joshbekashah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eighteenth chose Hanani, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The nineteenth chose Mallothi, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twentieth chose Eliathah, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twenty-first chose Hothir, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twenty-second chose Giddalti, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twenty-third chose Mahazioth, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twenty-fourth chose Romamti Ezer, his sons, and his relatives—12 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following were the divisions of the gatekeepers: For Korah’s descendants there was Meshelemiah, the son of Kore, from the descendants of Asaph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshelemiah’s sons were Zechariah (the firstborn), Jediael (the second), Zebadiah (the third), Jathniel (the fourth),
speaker: Narrator

text: Elam (the fifth), Jehohanan (the sixth), Eliehoenai (the seventh).
speaker: Narrator

text: Also for Korah’s descendants there were Obed Edom’s sons Shemaiah (the firstborn), Jehozabad (the second), Joah (the third), Sachar (the fourth), Nethanel (the fifth),
speaker: Narrator

text: Ammiel (the sixth), Issachar (the seventh), Peullethai (the eighth). Elohim had blessed Obed Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: His son Shemaiah had sons who ruled their families because they were soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shemaiah’s sons were Othni, and Othni’s skilled brothers Rephael, Obed, Elzabad, as well as Elihu and Semachiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these people were Obed Edom’s descendants. They, their sons, and their relatives were skilled and had the ability to perform the service. Obed Edom’s family included 62 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshelemiah’s sons and relatives were 18 skilled men.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Merari there were Hosah’s sons. Shimri was the head, although he was not the firstborn. His father appointed him head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hosah’s other sons were Hilkiah (the second), Tebaliah (the third), and Zechariah (the fourth). There were 13 sons and relatives of Hosah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These divisions of gatekeepers through their head men were assigned duties with their relatives to serve in Yahweh’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: They drew lots by families, youngest and oldest alike, for every gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelemiah was chosen for the east side. His son Zechariah, a counselor who displayed insight, was chosen for the north side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obed Edom was chosen for the south side, and his sons were chosen for the storerooms.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shuppim and Hosah were chosen for the west side with Shallecheth Gate at the gateway that goes to the palace.
One squad of guards served its watch after another.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the east side there were six Levites. On the north there were four every day. On the south there were four every day. At the storerooms there were four, two at each entrance.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the courtyard on the west there were four Levites at the gateway to the palace and two at the courtyard itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the divisions of the gatekeepers among Korah’s and Merari’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahijah, a Levite, was in charge of the treasuries in Elohim’s temple and the treasuries of the gifts dedicated to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were also the descendants of Ladan, who was descended from Gershon. Those who served for Ladan, the descendant of Gershon, were the heads of Ladan’s families: Jehiel
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jehiel’s sons Zetham and Joel. They were in charge of the treasuries in Yahweh’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the descendants of Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel,
speaker: Narrator

text: there was Shebuel, a descendant of Moses’ son Gershom. He was the highest-ranking official in charge of the treasuries.
speaker: Narrator

text: From his relatives on Eliezer’s side of the family was Shelomith. (Eliezer’s son was Rehabiah; his grandson was Jeshaiah; his great-grandson was Joram. Joram’s son was Zichri; his grandson was Shelomith.)
speaker: Narrator

text: He and his relatives were in charge of all the treasuries of the gifts dedicated to God that King David, the heads of families, the commanders of regiments and battalions, and the commanders of the army had donated.
speaker: Narrator

text: (They had donated some of the loot taken in battle to support Yahweh’s temple.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything that Samuel the seer, Saul (son of Kish), Abner (son of Ner), and Joab (son of Zeruiah) had donated—everything that had been donated—was under the supervision of Shelomith and his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Izhar’s descendants Chenaniah and his sons were assigned duties. They served as officials and judges outside the temple in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Hebron’s descendants Hashabiah and his 1,700 skilled, male relatives were appointed to serve Israel west of the Jordan River. They did everything Yahweh wanted them to do, and they served the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeriah was the head of Hebron’s descendants. In the fortieth year of David’s reign, the ancestry of Hebron’s descendants was researched family by family. Warriors from these families were found at Jazer in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeriah’s relatives were 2,700 skilled men, who were heads of families. King David appointed them to be overseers in every matter involving Elohim or the king for the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a list of Israelite family heads, regiment and battalion commanders, and officers who were serving the king in all the army’s units. Throughout each year they came for a month at a time and then left. Each unit consisted of 24,000 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jashobeam, son of Zabdiel, was in charge of the first unit, the one during the first month. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was a descendant of Perez, and he was head of all of the army’s officers for the first month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dodai, Ahoh’s descendant, was in charge of the unit during the second month. It was his unit. (Mikloth was one of its leaders.) In Dodai’s unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third commander of the army during the third month was Benaiah, son of the priest Jehoiada. He was the head, and in his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: This Benaiah was one of the thirty fighting men and commander of the thirty as well as his own unit. His son was Ammizabad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asahel, Joab’s brother, was in charge of the fourth unit during the fourth month, and after him was his son Zebadiah. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shamhuth, Izrah’s descendant, was commander of the fifth unit during the fifth month. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ira, the son of Ikkesh from Tekoa, was in charge of the sixth unit during the sixth month. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Helez, a Pelonite from the descendants of Ephraim, was in charge of the seventh unit during the seventh month. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sibbecai, a descendant of Zerah from Hushah, was in charge of the eighth unit during the eighth month. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiezer, a member of the tribe of Benjamin from Anathoth, was in charge of the ninth unit during the ninth month. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahrai, a descendant of Zerah from Netophah, was in charge of the tenth unit during the tenth month. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah, a member of the tribe of Ephraim from Pirathon, was in charge of the eleventh unit during the eleventh month. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the twelfth month, the twelfth unit was commanded by Heldai from Netophah. He was Othniel’s descendant. In his unit there were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The following officers were in charge of the tribes of Israel:
for the tribe of Reuben
Eliezer, son of Zichri
for the tribe of Simeon
Shephatiah, son of Maacah
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the tribe of Levi
Hashabiah, son of Kemuel
for the family of Aaron
Zadok
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the tribe of Judah
Elihu, one of David’s brothers
for the tribe of Issachar
Omri, son of Michael
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the tribe of Zebulun
Ishmaiah, son of Obadiah
for the tribe of Naphtali
Jerimoth, son of Azriel
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the tribe of Ephraim
Hoshea, son of Azaziah
for half of the tribe of Manasseh
Joel, son of Pedaiah
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the half of Manasseh in Gilead
Iddo, son of Zechariah
for the tribe of Benjamin
Jaasiel, son of Abner
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the tribe of Dan
Azarel, son of Jeroham
These were the commanders of Israel’s tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: David didn’t count those under 20 years old, because Yahweh had promised that the people of Israel would be as numerous as the stars in the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab, son of Zeruiah, started to count them but didn’t finish. God was angry with Israel because of this, and the report from it was never included in the official records of King David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were all the commanders in charge of King David’s property:
for the royal treasuries
Azmaveth, son of Adiel
for the goods in the fields, cities, villages, and watchtowers
Jonathan, son of Uzziah
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the farm workers in the fields
Ezri, son of Chelub
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the vineyards
Shimei from Ramah
for storing wine that came from the vineyards
Zabdi from Shepham
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the olive and fig trees in the foothills
Baal Hanan from Gedor
for storing olive oil
Joash
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the herds grazing in Sharon
Shitrai from Sharon
for the herds in the valleys
Shaphat, son of Adlai
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the camels
Obil, a descendant of Ishmael
for the donkeys
Jehdeiah from Meronoth
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the flocks
Jaziz from Hagar
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s uncle Jonathan, an educated man who possessed insight, was David’s adviser. Jonathan and Jehiel, son of Hachmoni, were in charge of the king’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel was the king’s adviser. Hushai, a descendant of Archi, was the king’s friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada (son of Benaiah) and Abiathar succeeded Ahithophel. Joab was the commander of the royal army.
speaker: Narrator

text: David held a meeting in Jerusalem for all the leaders of Israel—the leaders of the tribes, the leaders of the army units that served the king, the commanders of regiments and battalions, the officials in charge of all the property and livestock belonging to the king and his sons, the palace officials, the soldiers, and the fighting men.
speaker: Narrator

text: David stood in front of them and said, “Listen to me, my relatives and subjects. I had my heart set on building the temple where the ark of Yahweh’s promise could be placed. This temple would be a stool for our Elohim’s feet, and I have made preparations to build it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elohim told me, ‘You must not build the temple for my name. You have fought wars and caused bloodshed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, from my entire family Yahweh Elohim of Israel chose me to be king of Israel permanently. He had chosen the tribe of Judah to lead Israel. From the families of Judah he chose my father’s family. From among my father’s sons he was pleased to make me king of all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And of all my sons (Yahweh has given me many sons) he chose my son Solomon to sit on the throne of Yahweh’s kingdom to rule Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “He told me, ‘Your son Solomon will build my temple and my courtyards because I have chosen him to be my son. I will be his Ab.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish his kingdom forever if he will remain determined to obey my commands and laws, as he is doing today.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, leaders, I order you in the sight of Israel (Yahweh’s congregation) and as our Elohim listens to dedicate your lives to doing everything Yahweh your Elohim has commanded. Then you will be able to possess this good land and leave it as an inheritance to your descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And you, my son Solomon, learn to know your father’s Elohim. Serve Yahweh wholeheartedly and willingly because he searches every heart and understands every thought we have. If you dedicate your life to serving him, he will accept you. But if you abandon him, he will reject you from then on.
speaker: Narrator

text: So be careful, because Yahweh has chosen you to build the temple as his holy place. Be strong, and do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David gave his son Solomon the plans for the entrance hall and the temple, its storerooms, upper rooms, inner rooms, and the room for the throne of mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave him plans for the courtyards of Yahweh’s temple and for all the rooms around it. (These rooms served as treasuries for Elohim’s temple and the gifts dedicated to God.)
speaker: Narrator

text: He determined the divisions of priests and Levites. He planned all the work done for worship in Yahweh’s temple. He designed all the utensils for worship in Yahweh’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: David specified the weight of gold to be used for each of the utensils for worship,
speaker: Narrator

text: the weight of the gold lamp stands and their gold lamps (that is, the weight of gold for each lamp stand and its lamps), the weight of silver for each silver lamp stand and its lamps (according to the use of each lamp stand for worship),
speaker: Narrator

text: the weight of gold for each table with the rows of bread, and the silver for the silver tables,
speaker: Narrator

text: the pure gold for the forks, bowls, and pitchers, the weight of each gold bowl, the weight of each silver bowl,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the refined gold for the altar of incense. He also gave Solomon the plans for the chariot, that is, the gold angels with their wings spread to cover the ark of Yahweh’s promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “All this was written for me by Yahweh’s hand. He made all the details of the plan clear to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David also told his son Solomon, “Be strong and courageous, and do the work. Don’t be afraid or terrified. Yahweh Elohim, my Elohim, will be with you. He will not abandon you before all the work on Yahweh’s temple is finished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here are also the divisions of the priests and Levites for every type of worship in Elohim’s temple. You have with you every skilled worker to do all the work. In addition, all the leaders and people are at your command.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King David said to the whole assembly, “My son Solomon, the one whom Elohim has chosen, is young and inexperienced. Yet, the work is important because this palace is not for a person but for Yahweh Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: With all my might I gathered the materials for the temple of my Elohim: gold for gold objects, silver for silver objects, bronze for bronze objects, iron for iron objects, wood for wooden objects, onyx stones and settings, black stones, stones of different colors, gems, and marble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, I delight in the temple of my Elohim. I have a personal treasury of gold and silver that I’m giving to my Elohim’s temple in addition to everything else I gathered for the holy temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: There are 225,000 pounds of gold from Ophir and 525,000 pounds of refined silver. They are to be used to cover the walls of the buildings,
speaker: Narrator

text: to make gold objects, silver objects, and everything else the craftsmen will make. Who else is willing to make an offering and dedicate himself to Yahweh today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of the families, the leaders of the tribes of Israel, the commanders of regiments and battalions, and the officials in charge of the king’s work gave generously.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave 375,186 pounds of gold, 750,000 pounds of silver, 135,000 pounds of bronze, and 7,500,000 pounds of iron for the work on Elohim’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever happened to have precious stones gave them to Jehiel, Gershon’s descendant, for the treasury of Yahweh’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people were overjoyed that the leaders gave so generously and wholeheartedly to Yahweh.
King David was also overjoyed, and
speaker: Narrator

text:
he praised Yahweh while the whole assembly watched. David said,
“May you be praised, Yahweh Elohim of Israel,
    our father forever and ever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Greatness, power, splendor, glory, and majesty are yours, Yahweh,
    because everything in heaven and on earth is yours.
        The kingdom is yours, Yahweh,
            and you are honored as head of all things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Riches and honor are in front of you.
    You rule everything.
        You hold power and strength in your hands,
            and you can make anyone great and strong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Our Elohim, we thank you
    and praise your wonderful name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But who am I and who are my people
    that you enable us to give so generously?
        Everything comes from you.
            We give you only what has come from your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To you we are all like our ancestors—
    foreigners without permanent homes.
        Our days are as fleeting as shadows on the ground.
            There’s no hope for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yahweh, our Elohim, all this wealth that we gathered to build a temple for your holy name is from you. All of it is yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know, my Elohim, that you examine hearts and delight in honesty. With an honest heart I have willingly offered all these things. I’ve been overjoyed to see your people here offering so willingly to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh Elohim of our ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, always watch over your people’s deepest thoughts. Keep their hearts directed toward you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make my son Solomon completely committed to you so that he will obey your commands, requests, and laws and do everything to build the palace I have planned.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to the whole assembly, “Praise Yahweh your Elohim!” So the whole assembly praised Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors and knelt in front of Yahweh and the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day they sacrificed to Yahweh. They sacrificed burnt offerings to Yahweh: 1,000 bulls, 1,000 rams, 1,000 lambs, wine offerings, and many sacrifices for all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day they ate and drank as they joyfully celebrated in front of Yahweh. For the second time they made David’s son Solomon king. On Yahweh’s behalf they anointed Solomon to be leader and Zadok to be the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon sat on Yahweh’s throne as king in place of his father David. Solomon was successful and all Israel obeyed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the leaders and soldiers and all of King David’s sons pledged their loyalty to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh made Solomon extremely powerful, as all Israel could see. The people of Israel gave him royal honor like no king of Israel before him ever had.
speaker: Narrator

text: David, son of Jesse, had ruled all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ruled as king of Israel for 40 years. He ruled for 7 years in Hebron and for 33 in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He died at a very old age. His long life was full of wealth and honor. Then his son Solomon succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything about King David from first to last is written in the records of the seer Samuel, the prophet Nathan, and the seer Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: It includes everything about his reign, his power, and the things that happened to him, Israel, and all the other kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator
